--- format: revealjs: theme: [default, custom.scss] slide-number: true --- ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## Panel Surveys {.center background-color="#ac1455"}   **POLSCI 4SS3** Winter 2023 ::: ## Announcements {background-color="#8BD3E6"} - Lab 2 deadline extended to Friday, January 27 `(no new lab today)` - [Sign up for groups!](https://forms.gle/6MpV3XfQjpvCd2pS6) - By 9 AM tomorrow or I will put you wherever {{< fa face-angry >}} ## Last week {background-color="#FDBF57"} - Overview of **MIDA** approach to research design as programming - **Representative surveys** as the gold standard of public opinion research - Challenging to decide: - What to ask - Who to ask - **Lab:** Get to know R, practice simulating a survey with random sampling ## Today {background-color="#FDBF57"} - Start thinking about **cause and effect** - **Panel surveys:** Survey the same sample multiple times - **Lab:** Revisit last week's lab ::: {style="text-align: center"} # Cause and Effect {background-color="#FDBF57"} ::: ## Elements of a model {{< fa book >}} . . . 1. Signature 2. Functional relations 3. Probability distribution over exogenous variables ## Part 1: Signature ::: incremental - **{{< fa book >}}:** Describes variables and their ranges - Two kinds of variables - **Endogenous:** Generated from *within* the model - **Exogenous:** Generated from *without* the model ::: ## Types of exogenous variables ::: incremental 1. Anything explicitly (or assumed as) **randomized** - Mostly experimental treatment assignment - Denoted by $Z$ 2. Anything **unobserved** by the model - Otherwise we would be in trouble! - Denoted by $U$ ::: ## Types of endogenous variables - Anything else ::: incremental - **Outcomes:** The things we ultimately want to understand ($Y$) - **Moderators:** Variables that modify effects ($X$) - **Mediators:** How or why something has an effect ($X$) - **Confounders:** Introduce non-causal dependence ($X$) ::: ## Part 2: Functional relations ::: incremental - **{{< fa book >}}:** Set of **functions** that produce endogenous variables - Two ways to express functional relations 1. **Structural causal models** `(today)` 2. **Potential outcomes framework** `(next week)` ::: ## Structural causal models - Use **D**irected **A**cyclic **G**raphs `(DAGs)` ::: incremental - **Directed:** Connected by arrows - **Acyclic:** Not cyclical, usually end in outcomes - **Graphs:** Visual representation as *nodes* and *edges* - They represent **nonparametric** causal models ::: ## Example ::: {.cell-output-display} ![DAG for $Y = f_y(Z,U)$](03_slides_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-1-1.png){width=960} ::: ## Part 3: Probability distribution over exogenous variables - An explanation of how exogenous variables are generated . . . ### Examples . . . - $Z \sim \text{Bern}(p)$ with $p = 0.1$ . . . - $U \sim N(\mu, \sigma)$ with $\mu = 0$ and $\sigma = 1$ ::: {style="text-align: center"} # Panel Surveys {background-color="#FDBF57"} ::: ## What are panel surveys? ::: incremental - Surveys where the same participants are asked questions at multiple points in time - Usually measure **outcomes** at every time `(but not necessary)` - More common among *convenience samples* `(e.g. students, twins)` - The name comes from their **data structure** ::: ## Panel data ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Balanced panel
ID year income age sex
1 2016 1300 27 M
1 2017 1600 28 M
1 2018 2000 29 M
2 2016 2000 38 F
2 2017 2300 39 F
2 2018 2400 40 F
````` ::: ## Panel data ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Unbalanced panel
ID year income age sex
1 2016 1600 23 M
1 2017 1500 24 M
2 2016 1900 41 F
2 2017 2000 42 F
2 2018 2100 43 F
3 2017 3300 34 M
````` ::: ## What are panel surveys for? ::: {.fragment .semi-fade-out fragment-index=1} 1. To measure attitudes in a population over time ::: ::: {.fragment .highlight-red fragment-index=1} 2. To understand the effect of events occurring between waves ::: ## Challenge ::: incremental - **Panel attrition:** Participants may drop out from follow up waves - It may offset the benefit of conducting a panel survey - It may depend on factors relevant to the study ::: ## Example 1 ![](figs/esaiasson_persson_0.png){fig-align="center"} --- ![](figs/esaiasson_persson_1.png){fig-align="center"} ## Example 2 ![](figs/claes_hooghe_0.png){fig-align="center"} --- ![](figs/claes_hooghe_1.png){fig-align="center"} --- ![](figs/claes_hooghe_2.png){fig-align="center"} ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## Next Week {.center background-color="#8BD3E6"} ### Sensitive Questions **Focus on:** Which research design seems more appropriate to elicit honest answers? ::: ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## Break time! {.center background-color="#D2D755"}   ![](figs/panda_dance.gif){fig-align="center" width="10%" height="10%"} ::: ::: {style="text-align: center"} ## {{< fa laptop-code >}} Lab {.center background-color="#007096"} :::

<script>
  // htmlwidgets need to know to resize themselves when slides are shown/hidden.
  // Fire the "slideenter" event (handled by htmlwidgets.js) when the current
  // slide changes (different for each slide format).
  (function () {
    // dispatch for htmlwidgets
    function fireSlideEnter() {
      const event = window.document.createEvent("Event");
      event.initEvent("slideenter", true, true);
      window.document.dispatchEvent(event);
    }

    function fireSlideChanged(previousSlide, currentSlide) {
      fireSlideEnter();

      // dispatch for shiny
      if (window.jQuery) {
        if (previousSlide) {
          window.jQuery(previousSlide).trigger("hidden");
        }
        if (currentSlide) {
          window.jQuery(currentSlide).trigger("shown");
        }
      }
    }

    // hookup for slidy
    if (window.w3c_slidy) {
      window.w3c_slidy.add_observer(function (slide_num) {
        // slide_num starts at position 1
        fireSlideChanged(null, w3c_slidy.slides[slide_num - 1]);
      });
    }

  })();
</script>
